Dear Megan Zambiasi:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation While restraining Youth N on 2/13/24 Staff 1 intentionally stepped
on Youth N's foot and scratched her face drawing blood.
Investigation Video
Video shows Staff 2 guiding Youth N down a hallway. Another
camera shows Youth N charge at Staff 2 attempting to push past
her into an undesignated area. Youth N repeatedly kicks a door
leading to offices. A third camera shows Staff 1 and Staff 2 with
Youth N in a two-person standing control hold. Youth N is
struggling and hitting Staff 1. The restraint moves out of the
camera’s view and continues for another minute. Staff 3
approaches and appears to try to verbally de-escalate the youth
while Staff 1 and Staff 2 are holding her. Staff 3 appears to switch
out with Staff 1 and Staff 1 leaves the area. Staff 2 and Staff 3
come into the camera’s view struggling to immobilize Youth N
using the two-person control hold. Staff 1 returns to the area to
assist them. Youth N moves the staff to the center of the room
and drops to a sitting position behind furniture. Staff 1, Staff 2 and
Staff 3 continue holding her limbs. Youth N has ahold of Staff 1’s
braids. Staff 1 gets free. Youth N pushes herself back to a lying
position on the floor and kicks up at Staff 2 and Staff 3. Staff 5
enters the room. Staff 2 bends over Youth N’s torso and
reengages holding her arms while Staff 3 grabs and holds each of
Youth N’s feet to the floor. Staff 5 eventually switches with Staff 3
and holds the youth’s ankles up from the floor. Video does not
show Staff 1 scratching Youth N’s face or stepping on her foot.
Documents reviewed:
Assessment by Nurse 1 on 2/13/24 indicated “per youth she was
physically managed after assaulting a staff member…Youth has
several superficial scratches to her face. 3-inch scratch to Left
2

cheek, 3-inch scratch to right side of nose, and 1 inch scratch to
Right side of cheek. Writer cleansed areas with antiseptic and
applied bacitracin to scraped areas youth tolerated well. youth
denied any other injuries currently. Writer checked arms, back and
torso area, all negative for injury. Youth was very upset during
assessment, was on the phone speaking with family and tearful,
Writer offered youth 10mg PRN Thorazine which youth accepted.
Youth also took Motrin for pain and stiffness and refused ice pack.
Writer informed unit manager youth’s injuries.”
A photo of Youth N’s face taken by Government Worker 1 on
2/15/24 showed the following:
• One 1-inch scratch on her lower right jaw.
• One 1 ½- inch scratch on her right nostril.
• One 1-inch scratch on her lower left cheek.
• One ½ -inch healing scratch above her right upper lip.
• One 1-inch red mark left of her nose.
An incident report spanning over an hour on 02/13/24 indicated
Youth N became belligerent, was kicking a door and would not
respond to verbal de-escalation by staff. She kicked Staff 2 and
punched Staff 1 in the face. Youth N was physically restrained for
one minute. Once released, she ran to Staff 1 and struck her
again multiple times in the face. Efforts to escort her failed. Youth
N then hit Staff 2 in the face and fell to the floor kicking, spitting,
biting and punching her. Another attempt to physically manage
her failed after one minute. Staff 2 directed Staff 1 to leave the
area…Staff 4 stepped onto the wing…Youth N reported scratches
on her face. Staff 2 had a bruise and two bite marks on her hand.
Nurse was notified.
A body chart completed on 2/11/24 indicated Youth N had a
scratch to the right side of her nose. A body chart completed after
this incident on 2/13/24 indicated in addition to the scratch
detected on 2/11/24, Youth N had four new scratches on her face.
Staff 1’s disciplinary write-ups include a verbal warning on
12/20/22, written warning on 1/24/23, counseling memo on
2/15/23 and violation of policy on 5/23/23. Only the verbal
warning on 12/20/22 involved a client-related issue.
Interviews
Complainant/Therapist reported this allegation on behalf of Youth
N. She did not witness the incident and had no additional
information.
3

I notified Youth N’s Foster Care Worker of the investigation
assignment, and she expressed no additional concerns.
I interviewed Youth N jointly with Government Worker 1 on
2/15/24. She has been at the facility for nine months. Youth N
presented with vertical superficial scratches on her right lower
cheek, nose and left cheek. She said a nurse applied ointment to
her scratches and told her they would heal. Youth N stated she
did not have her foot checked out insisting “Nothing’s wrong with
it. It’s just a scratch on a toe.” With encouragement, Youth N
allowed Government Worker 1 to photograph her face but refused
to show us her foot.
Youth N said Staff 1 caused the injuries and intentionally
scratched her after Youth N hit Staff 1 in her face or head. Staff
cleared the area of other youths and restrained her. “Staff 1 was
saying stuff to me while I was being restrained…She (Staff 1) put
her hand over my face and mouth and stepped on my foot.”
Youth N explained Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4 and Staff 5 restricted
her movement in different ways. “Staff 2 and Staff 4 were on each
side. I sat down so they’d let me go. Staff 5 held my feet down.
They let go and I walked somewhere else.”
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer via Teams on 3/5/24. Staff 2 is a team leader with 12
years of experience working in child caring institutions. She was
last trained in CPI in November 2023. Staff 2 recalled the incident
on 2/13/24. She said Youth N was kicking a door and she and
Staff 1 tried to verbally de-escalate her. “Youth N punched me
and Staff 1.” In response Staff 1 and Staff 2 attempted to put her
in a two-person control hold for one minute but were unsuccessful
because Youth N was struggling and hitting. “We got her into a
proper hold. She dropped and sat on the floor. Staff 1 and I
disengaged. Youth N punched Staff 1 in the face and held onto
her hair. I tried to get her to release, but she had a good grip.
Once Youth N released Staff 1’s hair, she kicked me and Staff 1’s
legs. Staff 1 and I put her in another two-person control hold for
less than one minute. Youth N fell to the floor and we
disengaged. Staff 3 arrived and assisted removing Staff 1
because I felt like Staff 1 was a target since Youth H had punched
her and pulled her hair.”
Staff 2 denied seeing Staff 1 intentionally step on Youth N’s foot. I
asked Staff 2 if Youth N spit at Staff 1. She said she did, but she
did not see Staff 1 scratch the youth or rub the spit in her face. “I
did see scratches on Youth N’s face after but I knew she was in a
4

physical management the day before.” Staff 2 did not recall Staff
5 responding at the scene or holding Youth N’s feet as seen in the
video.
I interviewed Staff 4 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer present on 2/15/24. Government Worker 1 read the
allegation aloud. Staff 4 has worked at the facility for nine months.
When he arrived on the wing, he said Youth N was hitting doors
and had scratches on her face. “Youth N walked up and grabbed
onto Staff 2’s hands. Youth N pulled her own hair and me and
Staff 2 stopped her, using the two-person control hold. Youth N
sat on the floor, kicked walls and pulled her own hair. She did not
pull staff’s hair.” Staff 2 said he did write an incident report and
did not notice any of the staff do anything inappropriate.
I interviewed Staff 5 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Rights
Officer present. She has worked at the facility for ten months and
was last trained in CPI in July 2023. Staff 5 recalled Youth N
screaming and kicking Staff 3. “Staff 2 and 3 were trying to
restrain her. Youth N hit, bit and kicked. She bit Staff 2 on the
hand. I tried to restrain her legs. She was still on the floor. I
stopped her legs from kicking. Youth N got up, rand around and
went after Staff 1. They had Staff 1 get off the wing. Youth N
already had scratches on her face. Youth N grabbed her own hair
begging to go into her therapist’s office…I don’t know anything
about her foot.”
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 on 2/23/24
with Rights Officer present. She has worked at the facility for 18
months and was last trained in CPI in July 2023. Staff 1 said
Youth N became belligerent and would not respond to Staff 2’s
directions. “Staff 2 attempted to restrain her. I tried to de-
escalate. Youth N reached across and hit my shoulder. I stepped
next to Staff 2 and tried to restrain Youth N. Youth N spit in my
hand and I grabbed her face. She struggled away from my hand.
She broke every single nail on my hand. That is how her face got
scratched. I never reached for her or attacked her…We never
restrained her successfully. Staff 3 came. Youth N was furious
and focused on me. I walked off the wing.”
Staff 1 was uncertain if Youth N fell to the floor or if she stepped
on Youth N’s foot. “It was very bad for her to spit. I know I
grabbed her mouth for a matter of seconds.” Staff 1 demonstrated
how she placed her full open hand over Youth N’s mouth and
face. I asked about the protocol for responding to a youth spitting.
Staff 1 did not know. Rights Officer indicated that when readily
5

available, staff may use a towel or cushion to shield themselves
from being spit on. He said face shields are also available for use
with youths who are known to spit.
Government Worker 1 deemed Staff 1 unsuitable to work with
children.
Analysis In response to Youth N spitting on her, Staff 1 admitted she
grabbed Youth N’s face, covered her face and mouth with her
hand and scratched her breaking all of her fingernails. There is no
evidence Staff 1 intentionally injured or stepped on the youth’s
foot.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Behavior management
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4157
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents,
their families, and referring agencies.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff used improper techniques when restraining Youth N.
Investigation Video
Youth N moves the staff to the center of the room and drops to a
sitting position behind furniture. Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3
continue holding her limbs…Youth N pushes herself back to a
lying position on the floor…Staff 2 bends over Youth N’s torso and
reengages holding her arms while Staff 3 grabs and holds each of
Youth N’s feet to the floor. Staff 5 eventually switches with Staff 3
and holds the youth’s ankles up from the floor.
Document reviewed
I reviewed the CPI restraint moves used and approved by the
facility. No move involves staff restraining any part of a youth’s
body when the youth is sitting or lying on the floor.
Interview
6

Staff 5 admitted she restrained Youth N’s legs to stop her from
kicking on the floor.
Analysis Holding any part of a youth’s body when she is sitting or lying on
the floor are not restraint moves described in the institution’s
behavior management system.
Video shows Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 continued holding her
limbs after Youth N dropped to a sitting position. She transitioned
into a lying position and Staff 2 continued holding her upper body
while Staff 3 held her ankles to the floor and Staff 5 subsequently
held her ankles up from the floor.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
